questiontext.text: Put the main milestones and events important for the development of the European conventional arms control system in a chronological order, starting from the oldest event:

subquestion.text: Entry into force of the Open Skies Treaty
Suspension of the implementation of the CFE Treaty by Russia
Activation of risk reduction and emergency procedures of the Vienna Document and Open Skies Treaty in the context of the conflict in Eastern Ukraine

questiontext.text: The European system of conventional arms control emerged in response to some specific security challenges. Which of the sentences describing its basic aims are correct? (more than one answer is possible)

answer.text: minimize the threat of a major war on the continent
establish mechanisms for fighting terrorism
prevent the trafficking of weapons of mass destruction and related materials
build trust between the states

questiontext.text: One of the  positive developments in European conventional arms control was setting up of a sub-regional conventional arms control system in Western Balkans in the 1990s. What was its main achievement?

answer.text: more than 10,000 pieces of heavy weaponry were destroyed
more than 1,000 pieces of heavy weaponry were destroyed
no new heavy weapons were bought by the countries in the region
no new heavy artillery and tanks were bought by the countries in the region

questiontext.text: Towards the end of the Cold War, work on the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty was initiated to manage the confrontation between two military blocks. What were those blocks?

answer.text: NATO and Tashkent Treaty Organization
Western European Union and Warsaw Pact
European Union and Warsaw Pact
NATO and Warsaw Pact

questiontext.text: The CFE Treaty includes a list of Treaty-Limited Equipment (TLE). Which of the following categories of conventional weapons is not limited by the Treaty?

answer.text: combat aircraft
tanks
drones
heavy artillery

questiontext.text: Major reductions of Treaty-Limited Equipment (TLE), or specific types of heavy conventional weapons, took place between 1992 and 1995. How many pieces of TLE were eliminated or converted in accordance with the Treaty?

answer.text: approximately 8 thousand
over 20 thousand
over 50 thousand
over 80 thousand

questiontext.text: The CFE Treaty included the so-called host nation consent rule. In essence, it means that:

answer.text: no foreign conventional forces can be stationed on the territory of some of its signatories
no foreign conventional forces can be stationed on one’s territory without agreement of the host state
no foreign conventional forces can be stationed on one’s territory without agreement of the host state, confirmed by a referendum
no foreign nuclear forces can be stationed on the territory of some of its signatories

questiontext.text: The CFE Treaty does not cover all the territories of the participating states, but has a specific area of application. The CFE covers:

answer.text: territory of the States Parties in Europe between the Atlantic and the Volga river
territory of the States Parties in Europe, excluding Turkey
territory of the States Parties in Europe and Western Coast of the United States
territory of the States Parties in Europe from the Atlantic to the Ural Mountains

questiontext.text: Russia, one of the parties to the CFE Treaty, argued since early 2000s that its continued application is detrimental to its security interests and called on NATO countries to ratify the Adapted CFE as soon as possible. What decision did it take in 2007?

answer.text: Russia officially withdrew from the CFE Treaty
Russia suspended implementation of CFE commitments only with regards to NATO countries
Russia suspended implementation of the CFE
Russia suspended implementation of CFE commitments only with regards to the United States

questiontext.text: The Vienna Document on Confidence and Security Building Measures was agreed between the Participating States of the OSCE. The document:

answer.text: includes legally binding commitments
includes both politically binding pledges and legally binding commitments
includes politically binding pledges
remains a statement of intent

questiontext.text: A number of states in Europe organize so-called snap exercises to test the responsiveness and readiness of their armed forces. According to the Vienna Document, such exercises...

answer.text: need to be notified to other countries in advance
need to be notified to other countries in advance using confidential channels
need to be notified only to the neighbours of the conducting country
do not need to be notified in advance

questiontext.text: The Vienna Document includes a number of Confidence and Security Building Measures. From the list below, which one is NOT included in the VD?

answer.text: Exchange of information on military planning and doctrines
Exchange of information on number of nuclear warheads and their storage sites
Risk reduction mechanisms for dealing with unusual military activities and military incidents
Prior notification and invitation of observers to the so-called Certain Military Activities

questiontext.text: What are the origins of the Open Skies Treaty?

answer.text: Proposal made by NATO in 1949
Proposal made by U.S. President Dwight Eisenhower in 1955
Joint proposal of Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev  in 1986
Proposal made by U.S. President George Bush in 1991

questiontext.text: The Open Skies Treaty remains one of the cornerstones of the European conventional arms control. Which of the statements characterizing the Open Skies Treaty are correct? (more than one answer is possible)

answer.text: the Treaty permits conduct of observation flights by unarmed aircraft
the parties to the Treaty can prohibit flights over the areas where their most important military bases are located
each aircraft can carry only specially certified sensors
each state party is assigned a quota of observation flights that it is obliged to receive every year

questiontext.text: During Open Skies flights, the aircraft uses its certified cameras to record images. How broadly can these images be further distributed?

answer.text: They are only available to the observing country
They are only available to the observing and observed country
They are available to all State Parties, but they must request and pay for them
They are publicly available

questiontext.text: A number of critical milestones and events important for the development of the European conventional arms control system were mentioned in the presentations. Which of the following is the oldest event?

answer.text: Suspension of the implementation of the CFE Treaty by Russia
Activation of risk reduction and emergency procedures of the Vienna Document and Open Skies Treaty in the context of the conflict in Eastern Ukraine
Signing of the CFE Treaty
Entry into force of the Open Skies Treaty

questiontext.text: There is no precise definition of non-strategic nuclear weapons. Which definition listed below is the most accurate?

answer.text: weapon systems (warheads and associated delivery vehicles) that have never been covered by nuclear arms control treaties
nuclear weapons with a yield up to 10kt
nuclear warheads and associated delivery vehicles with a range of less than 500km
nuclear weapons which purpose is to destroy targets on the battlefield

questiontext.text: Which of the below statement is correct?

answer.text: the 2010 U.S.-Russia New START Treaty is the first nuclear arms control treaty which limits U.S. and Russia strategic and non-strategic nuclear weapons
a number of U.S. nuclear weapons based in Europe is disproportionally larger than a number of Russia’s non-strategic nuclear weapons
Russia and U.S./NATO are fully transparent about number, types, and locations of storage sites with non-strategic nuclear weapons
even though nuclear weapons could be categorized as strategic or non-strategic, any operational use of a nuclear weapon would have a strategic impact

questiontext.text: What are possible delivery means of non-strategic nuclear weapons?

answer.text: intercontinental ballistic missiles
short-range ballistic missiles
fighter-bombers
torpedoes

questiontext.text: Which of the European countries have never participated in any nuclear arms control treaty? (more than one answer is possible)

answer.text: Russia
UK
France
Portugal

questiontext.text: Which type of non-strategic nuclear weapons are currently assigned to NATO?

answer.text: Atomic demolition munition
B-61 gravity bombs delivered by dual-capable aircraft
"Honest John" rockets mounted on trucks
Pershing II ballistic missiles

questiontext.text: According to unofficial estimates the number of U.S. nuclear weapons in Europe is:

answer.text: About 200
Between 300 and 500
Less than 20

questiontext.text: According to unofficial estimate Russia possesses:

answer.text: About 200 operational non-strategic nuclear weapons
Less than 20 operational non-strategic nuclear weapons
Between 5000 and 6000 operational non-strategic nuclear weapons
About 2000 operational non-strategic nuclear weapons

questiontext.text: The sharpest non-strategic nuclear weapons post-Cold War reductions were a part of:

answer.text: 2010 U.S.-Russia New START Treaty
There were no reductions, but increase in numbers of non-strategic nuclear weapons in Europe
1991/1992  U.S. – Soviet Union/Russia Presidential Nuclear Initiatives
CFE Treaty

questiontext.text: Which country has the biggest and most diversified arsenal of non-strategic nuclear weapons?

answer.text: United States
United Kingdom
France
Russia

questiontext.text: The number of U.S. non-strategic nuclear weapons in Europe has been dramatically reduced. How substantial were the reductions?

answer.text: More than 95 percent since  the peak in 1970s.
More than 75 percent since  the height of the Cold War.
More than 60 percent since the height of the Cold War.
The statement is false. The number if U.S. nuclear weapons in Europe has not changed since the end of the Cold War.

questiontext.text: What are the basic aims of the European system of conventional arms control? (more than one option is possible)

answer.text: to minimize the threat of a major war on the continent
to establish mechanisms for fighting terrorism
to prevent the trafficking of weapons of mass destruction and related materials
to build trust between the states

questiontext.text: Which of the following categories of conventional weapons is not limited by the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe, or the CFE Treaty Treaty-Limited Equipment (TLE)?

answer.text: combat aircraft
tanks
drones
heavy artillery

questiontext.text: Which of the statements characterizing the Open Skies Treaty are correct? (more than one option possible)

answer.text: the Treaty permits conduct of observation flights by unarmed aircraft
the parties to the Treaty can prohibit flights over the areas where their most important military bases are located
each aircraft can carry only specially certified sensors
each state party is assigned a quota of observation flights that it is obliged to receive every year

questiontext.text: The Vienna Document Confidence and Security Building Measures...

answer.text: are legally binding
include both politically binding pledges and legally binding commitments
include politically binding pledges

questiontext.text: The sharpest non-strategic nuclear weapons post-Cold War reductions were a part of:

answer.text: 2010 U.S.-Russia New START Treaty
There were no reductions, but increase in numbers of non-strategic nuclear weapons in Europe
1991/1992  U.S. – Soviet Union/Russia Presidential Nuclear Initiatives
CFE Treaty
